Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Gulliver Innovative Learning: a Platform for Managing Kinesthetic Activities
Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent reports have stressed that students need to develop an integrated understanding of science throughout their education; particularly with a focus on core concepts in science. In recent years there has been growing concern regarding science education in the United States. The current United States education system falls short when compared to international programs; this is particularly prevalent at higher-grade levels and in scientific subjects. While some success has been achieved in increasing student achievement in reading and writing over the past few years, achievement in science has remained shockingly low. It is clear from these results that new tools and technologies are needed to engage students in science learning in meaningful ways.

The proposed project, Gulliver Innovative Learning (GIL) is a scalable educational technology that engages students in modeling scientific phenomena in a fun and exciting way, while at the same time helping students to better understand such phenomena. This project has the potential of substantially enhancing student success in introductory level STEM courses and of influencing scientific literacy among individuals to broaden student participation in such courses. GIL provides a powerful and memorable learning experience that will give students confidence in their ability to tackle STEM subjects. The GIL platform can be extended to teach many scientific concepts including medical phenomena. Through these engaging participation-based activities, students will develop a better understanding of the underlying concepts. Furthermore, through instant analysis of the usage data, instructors will receive feedback regarding the progress of their students, leading to knowledge of gaps in understanding and resulting in ways to further instruct difficult concepts. As a result, instructors will be able to use this information to help students make a better connection between interrelated ideas. The team expects to use the customer discovery process to identify a product-market fit and to explore different pricing and revenue models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this I-Corps project was to evaluate the product-market fit for an educational technology tool, Gulliver Innovative Learning (GIL), that actively engages students in simulating scientific and medical phenomena. This project to build a Business Model Canvas included work to identify appropriate Customer Segments, explore Channels and Pricing Models, and clarify the Value Propositions of our technology. The initial customer segment and business model were validated through extensive customer discovery interviews that demonstrated a clear value proposition in the discussed activities. The team discovered that the initial target customer segment includes hands-on-museums and science centers.

Results of this I-Corps project have been presented at multiple conferences both nationally and internationally. The presentations include: the NSF 2016 STEM for All Video Showcase (http://videohall.com/p/646); the 2015 American Chemical Society (ACS) regional conference; the 2015 European Science Education Research Association (ESERA) conference; international conferences on Learning and on applications of science learning (ATINER); and two National Science Foundation summits in DC, the 2016 NSF Cyberleraning summit and the 2016 NSF ITEST summit.

This project provided input which lead to the eventual commercialization of a technology that contributes to improved learning activities for museums, medical waiting rooms, and events. The project entrepreneurial leader (EL) continues to work on the commercialization of the GIL technology through the NSF SBIR program (Award #1621976) that focuses on PlayFlu (www.playflu.com) as the first activity out of many potential exciting activities for students. PlayFlu actively engages children to model the spread of the influenza disease (flu) by involving them in a kinesthetic activity where the kids play as a role in the spreading phenomenon. The PlayFlu activity is timely and relevant to student life and can make a broader impact on society beyond science and technology. The understanding of health and scientific phenomena, such as vaccination and the spread of disease, has the potential to alter individual habits and behaviors within households, families, and neighborhoods.  This type of activity and its cutting-edge technology provides a powerful and memorable learning experience that improves the health literacy of young students in a fun and exciting way. At the same time, it also fosters interest and confidence in science and related fields. Future advancements could extend to other scientific and medical phenomena. The methodology may also be used in other educational areas outside science subjects such as games for practicing pattern recognition, math factors, and spelling.

Findings from this project will inform (1) instructional technology educators and developers as to student usage of technology in education thereby assisting in the development of other technological educational systems, and (2) informal learning educators about educational activities that foster student interest in science and math.
